p: Eco-centric laws have been passed in countries including: Ecuador in 2008 [65], Bolivia in 2010 and 2012 [66] (Law of the Rights of Mother Earth and Law of Mother Earth) and Panama in 2022. Panama grants nature the “right to exist, persist, and regenerate its life cycles”, defined as a “unique, indivisible and self-regulating community of living beings, elements and eco-systems interrelated to each other that sustains, contains and reproduces all beings” [67]. Other eco-centric laws have been codified in Colombia, Mexico, Uganda, and are included in Chile’s proposed constitution. In the United States, rights of nature have been shaped at the local level in more than 30 instances, including in the states of Pennsylvania, Florida, Minnesota and Colorado.
